name: fabric-ca
text: <@U0PB67X4K|garisingh> has renamed the channel from "fabric-cop" to "fabric-ca"
I was on a plane yesterday and lost track of what was going on

purpose: Discussions about using and developing the fabric-ca component.  fabric-ca is a runtime component which issues cryptographic material which can be used to participate in a Fabric network.
text: <@U0PB67X4K|garisingh> set the channel purpose: Discussions about using and developing the fabric-ca component.  fabric-ca is a runtime component which issues cryptographic material which can be used to participate in a Fabric network.

So the latest latest is that this *channel is for discussions about using and developing the fabric-ca component.  fabric-ca is a runtime component which issues cryptographic material which can be used to participate in a Fabric network.*   :wink: More seriously, once the ci works, we’ll announce...
<@U3PBR406M|bur> has joined the channel
<@U38DC9CCF|yedendra> has joined the channel
:upside_down_face:
have you guys switched over to the new repo fabric-ca yet?
I thought we'd be able to rename the repo rather than create a new one
So we have that renamed + we also wanted the ability to keep a read-only copy under the “previous” name (for another week, just in case)
So `fabric-cop` is now read-only, and `fabric-ca` is “writable”. We are just testing.
ah ok
you guys decided to call the binary fabric-ca?
I thought it'd be ca or maybe fca
no biggie but cop was shorter to type
I prefer fabric-ca
i prefer ca than cop. ca sounds more explicit.
yes, I agee with that
it will just take a bit of time to retrain our fingers
<@U3TKE8X3M|bjorn> has joined the channel
right, and we have to keep the `fabric-` prefix, to indicate that’s for the fabric project, not the others. when some day we make it a general ca, then can just remove the prefix from its name.
<@U3U415W6T|jorgedr> has joined the channel
<@U3TNHH1NW|dknochen> has joined the channel
<@U0P2GSA8Z> all of your in-flight changes should exist on fabric-ca, and you _should_ be able to `git remote add ...` the new repo so you don't need to re-clone
<@U0UHG4VP1> ah, good point

```
{"code":0,"message":"missing destination name serial_number in *server.UserRecord”}
```
<@U13TWBRBL>: I’m looking.
<@U11MANG9G> let me know if you want help
<@U13TWBRBL>: thanks for the update (that it’s working)
<@U0S5KF44D> thanks, will do.
Will take you up on it pretty soon actually: I am planning to push some code changes and would love a few of you to try it out.
<@U11MANG9G> thanks for jumping on that issue, turns out to be a user error (my fault), thanks <@U0S5KF44D> for pinpointing the cause
A quick one, what do we want the new version of the COP_HOME env variable to be?
(It used to be `$HOME/.cop`)
Do we want `$HOME/.ca` or `$HOME/.fabric-ca` ?
Alphabetically: <@U0P2GSA8Z>, <@U0KM61BCP>, <@U0PB67X4K>, <@U13TWBRBL>, <@U0S5KF44D> ^^^
I do believe we need `FABRIC_CA_HOME` rather than `CA_HOME` (so it’s not a simple COP -> CA substitution)
I think at this point we should be consistent and use fabric-ca for everything
<@U0P2GSA8Z>: I agree, also as the binary is `fabric-ca`. Any objections, please let me know.
FABRIC_CA_HOME is  a bit long but I think it's ok
consistency is more important than shortness
maybe we just stop using env variables?  :wink:
well, that's a different topic :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U0PB67X4K> ^^^: Sounds like a dream!

I’m trying to have the minimal ‘NO-OP’ change for now. There is more to do (like the hidden folders, etc.) But in the meantime, the latest/I’m going with:

    `FABRIC_CA_HOME` <- `$HOME/.fabric-ca`
<@U0S5KF44D>: I’m updating the docs of the sdk-node accordingly.
<@U12KAHER1> Yeh, I know we used to recognize COP_HOME and thought I changed to FABRIC_CA_HOME in the transition.  Maybe that got dropped somehow?
I assume the "dream" is to support command line args for everything also.  That was my dream also but requires more cfssl changes ... or duplicating more cfssl code

<@U0S5KF44D>: I would not worry about env vars. It is a different topic… (which we can look into).

Re: the current ENV ones, yes, that’s fine. I am going to follow <@U0P2GSA8Z> ’s advice and change everything consistently with a fabric prefix.
So FABRIC_…. `.fabric-ca.db`, etc.
(just wanted to check with everybody)
Other than `./vendor/github.com/cloudflare/cfssl/transport/example/ca.json`  :wink:
Using server-config.json and client-config.json rather than fabric-ca.json allows no confusion over server vs client config
<@U11MANG9G> the above discussions sound good to me
<@U0S5KF44D>: sure. Not changing `non-cop` files
One exception: I am keeping: *hfc-ca* being `Hyperledger Fabric Client Certificate Authority`
Because it already has an `F`in HFC <=> h `f` c. I don’t want to repeat as `hfc-fabric-ca` is not appealing. We can revisit. Just a heads-up.
perhaps use nconf like approach to set configurations.

text: <@U38DC9CCF>: I have not ignored you - I’m not a node expert but I took a quick look (at the hierarchies and to me it looks good). At the moment we are still trying to figure out if we need any of them ENV VARs (for CFSSL or just in general). If you don’t mind -> I will get in touch with more questions when we are there.
<@U11MANG9G> sure anytime!
using parameters is better, because application layer can manipulate env variables between calls

Yes, my preferred hierarchy is:
  1. config files (that are checked-in to a version control system)
  2. command line parameters - that are mostly/logically for “overriding the default”
  3. env vars - as the absolute last resort
yes, this sounds good to me
Mainly for reproducibility (and this includes reporting issues)
this way i can have a couple of hfc client pointing to different network or different gopaths
Exactly!
The entire set-up/tear-down becomes a walk in the park
Just to be clear: I mean, in a nice park, good weather, sun-glasses, etc. along with checked-in configurations.
haha :slightly_smiling_face:
Thanks <@U11MANG9G> !
The term fabric is too general, there were several `fabric` projects already in different domains. So with `hyperledger`, it will be more explicit.
